section.title: Method
section.para: Two main steps are foreseen:

listitem.para: Description of the scientific problem and related scientific requirements: In this context, the WG asks scientific stakeholders to provide an overview/summary of their problem (with a short description of the scientific objectives), and to provide scientific requirements that could be measurable; this helps to identify the scientific requirements for which a possible HW/SW solution has the greatest impact. The main purpose is to provide a real value of the proposed solution to the users;
Definition of use cases and identification of system requirements (functional and non-functional) that are used as input to define a solution.

section.para: The main purpose is to identify system functional and system non-functional requirements that provide real value for the scientific project, i.e. to help to fulfill scientific requirements. System functional requirements define a function or a behaviour of a system. System non-functional requirements impose qualities and constraints on the design or implementation of the system (such as performance, security, or reliability).
In we report the template, that reflects the two steps depicted above. , and report a justification of the template. is a summary.

section.title: The template
section.para: Scientists, research engineers, hardware and software developers and vendors do not have a common language and terms; all WG participants need details and guidance that organise the information in a uniform way. For the purpose of this work the use cases must be readable by all involved stakeholders.

In this section we propose a template to collect Physical Science use cases from scientific stakeholders. This template could help to collect problem statements and solution requirements. With this template we will help stakeholders to extract useful information from their “problem” to better understand:

listitem.para: which scientific requirement the proposed solution should fulfill and
to better identify use cases/workflows/functional requirements and the context;
to avoid to omit information that is mandatory to extract a workflows;
to enable solutions with a real benefit for scientists.

section.para: The template is organized in sections and where some key questions or suggestions are presents.

entry.para: Name of the scientific project
Scientific objectives
Write some short statement about the scientific objectives of the scientific project for which the stakeholders want to resolve a problem.
This section is useful to put the scientific project under analysis in the general context. Define objectives, not requirements.
Scientific requirements and problem definition
Write a problem statement. Statement should include

listitem.para: What the problem is for the scientific project
Who is affected by it?
What is the impact of this problem on the scientific project?
Is there a proposed or a current (in-operation) solution?

entry.para: Identify here the scientific requirements that the solution can contribute to fulfill. The scientific requirements should be measurable.
The problem of …
affects …
and results in … (some scientific requirements that are not fulfilled/ that is too expensive to fulfill/ that should be better fulfilled)
List of measurable scientific requirements.
Underlying causes of a problem
Sometimes there is a problem behind the problem. It could be important to consists of finding underlying causes that may not be immediately apparent.
It is important to define which factors contribute to the problem.

para.emphasis: System requirements of the solution (a product/HW-SW solution)

entry.para: Identifies what portion of the ultimate scientific project will address.
Definition of solution system boundaries, e.g. with a context diagram or in a textual form.
Assumptions made while scope
Description of the workflow/main functional and non-functional requirements

It is possible to describe the solution in term of a workflow, a list of functional requirement (list the major features or user capabilities unique to the product) or a use case and provide a list of non-functional requirements.
This Note do not specify “how to” write requirements.

Guidelines: The final solution (hardware and software) depends by storage needs, computing power and programming techniques. Some questions are provided, but feel free to add any information that you think is important:

listitem.para: For an experiment, the data acquisition is one of the most important aspects and may require technologies capable of transmitting data between sensors and acquisition equipment in very short times and with low latencies. Could you describe the main system requirements of your data acquisition system? (e.g. data rate, latency, need of high precision synchronization protocols (PTP))

In some cases the data must be transferred from the acquisition site to the site for storage and data analysis. Could you describe the workflow? Do you need appropriate protocols to ensure the integrity of the data during transfer? Do you need compression techniques? Do you need public/private interfaces to access the data? Could you provide the main system requirements of your data transfer system?
If you perform simulations, could you describe the workflow? Could you provide the data rate and the storage size that your simulation generates?

Must the storage be accessible by more computing nodes simultaneously without any special requirements regarding performance? Must the storage be accessible by more computing nodes simultaneously, allowing high throughput values and the possibility of the available space to growth? Could you provide the main system requirements of your storage system (size, latency, rate, the number of read/write accesses, and so on)?
Does the storage require separate areas for data and metadata (e.g. to improve performance and security)?
Do you need an archive system? Could you provide the main system requirements of your archive system? Do you need in-memory databases? Do you need No-SQL databases?
Do you need a data preservation system? Could you provide the size and the number of years that the archive should last?
The code used for the analysis or simulation is implemented with a distributed memory programming paradigm (e.g. MPI)? Or the code make use of shared memory (e.g. OpenMP)?
Do you need distributed computing frameworks (e.g. Hadoop)?
Do you need stream computing frameworks (e.g. Spark)?
Is your code single thread/multithread/multiprocessing/vectorizable?
The code links numerical libraries? Which libraries?
The code performs the same operation on a large amount of data (SIMD programming paradigm)?
Do you require machine learning techniques for data mining?
Do you have specific software libraries (that maybe could require porting to the OpenPOWER architecture)?
Do you need some special equipment that should be connected to the data acquisition or data analysis system (e.g. FPGAs)

entry.para: Constraints
Restrictions on the solution space and major dependencies to external factors outside of the project’s control:

listitem.para: Economics (e.g., costs, licensing issues)
Politics (e.g., internal or external, interdepartmental issues)
Technology (e.g., choice of technology, interface with existing technologies/platforms)
Systems (e.g., existing system, compatibility issues)
Environment (e.g., legal/environmental/security/standards)
Schedule and resources (e.g., fixed schedule, team)

section.para: The following sections report a justification of the template.

section.title: Problem analysis and scientific requirements
section.para: It is important to have a summary of the problem that the scientific project covers/wants to resolve. The scientific stakeholders should extract some basic information from their problem domain.

The section “Scientific problem analysis” helps OPFPS members and ICT stakeholders to focus on useful information from the problem domain of the scientific project. In fact, this is a basic problem analysis procedure that help OPF members and ICT stakeholders to identify the real value for scientists in the resolution of their problems.
The first step is the identification of scientific objectives, i.e. the goals of the scientific project (section “Scientific objectives”).

The scientific requirements are needed to reach the scientific objectives. The scientific stakeholders should identify the scientific requirements of the project (in analogy with the “business requirements” for an enterprise) for which the proposed solution has the maximum impact, and to provide a metric that will be used to measure the effectiveness of the proposed solution (section “Scientific requirements and problem definition”).

The primary reason products/systems don’t help to improve/satisfy the right scientific requirements is because the scientific requirements have not been identified adequately or they have not been properly understood by the ICT stakeholders (section “Underlying causes of a problem”).
This step will help to define a reference solution for a workflow/system that will provide a real value for the scientific project (section “Benefits of a solution”).
For a justification of the problem analysis, and the impact on the requirement inception see .

section.title: System requirements
section.para: With the scientific requirements in mind the scientific stakeholders should define the system requirements of the HW/SW solution, i.e. the functional and non-functional requirements of the proposed system.
These are the main information about the product/solution:

listitem.para: Product Vision: describes what the product is (section “Vision of the solution”).

Project Scope: identifies what portion of the ultimate scientific project the current product/system will address, definition of solution system boundaries. A context diagram could be provided that shows a top-level view of a system and the system’s boundaries (section “Scope”).
Provide clear statements of assumptions (section “Assumptions”).

Functional requirements: It is possible to describe the solution in term of a workflow, a list of functional requirement or a use case ( ). List the major features or user capabilities unique to the new product. For non-functional requirements check for more details. See section “Description of the workflow/main functional and non-functional requirements”.
Identify the constraints: put limitations on the ability to deliver a solution as envisioned restricting the solution space (section “Constraints”).

section.title: Use cases and system functional requirements
section.para: A Use Case is a description of system behaviour in response to a request from one actor. We are collecting Use Cases (and related scenarios) starting from scientific requirements to

listitem.para: encourage a common understanding of requirements on system behaviour for all the involved stakeholders;
improve communication among WG participants, OPF members and Physical Science community at large;
discover and document issues related to requirements that are not covered by current hw/sw solutions/current technology;
give context to non-functional requirements.

section.title: The system (the solution)
section.para: The system, for which we collect system requirements could be a workflow or a dataflow (or part of a workflow) of a solution for a scientific project, a software library of a software framework that could be used as part of a workflow or a dataflow.

section.title: In a nutshell
section.para: With use cases/workflow/list of system requirements we describe a possible workflow/dataflow of a system and/or software library of a scientific project, using the template.
The workflow is a view of the functional requirements of the system, with attached system non-functional requirements.
A system could be a data analysis system or a software library/framework that covers some system requirements.

The proposed solution is a possibile solution, using OPF hardware and software, that implement a system of a scientific project, or that optimize an existing solution, or that optimize the use of software libraries/framework used/developed by the scientific community
The proposed solution contributes to achieving the scientific requirements of a scientific project.
